captions.text: Take a moment to read the following.
designed to make you decode each word.
Those with dyslexia experience that laborious pace
When most people think of dyslexia,
they think of seeing letters and words backwards,
like seeing "b" as "d" and vice versa,
or they might think people with dyslexia
The truth is people with dyslexia
see things the same way as everyone else.
Dyslexia is caused by a phonological processing problem,
have trouble not with seeing language
For example, if you heard the word cat
and then someone asked you, "Remove the 'c',"
what word would you have left?
This can be difficult for those with dyslexia.
students with dyslexia need to break the word
Time spent decoding makes it hard
These difficulties are more widespread and varied
Dyslexia affects up to one in five people.
One person might have mild dyslexia
while the next person has a profound case of it.
It's common to see one family member
has severe difficulty decoding even one syllable words,
The continuum and distribution of dyslexia
suggests a broader principle to bear in mind
as we look at how the brains of those with dyslexia
that because all our brains show differences
we shouldn't be so quick to label
or dismiss people living with these variations
People with neurobiological variations like dyslexia,
including such creative and inventive individuals
to be brilliant and successful in life.
the brains of those with dyslexia work.
The brain is divided into two hemispheres.
The left hemisphere is generally in charge of language
while the right typically handles spatial activities.
that the brains of those with dyslexia
rely more on the right hemisphere and frontal lobe
than the brains of those without it.
This means, when they read a word,
it takes a longer trip through their brain
and can get delayed in the frontal lobe.
and teaches the reader to decode
based on syllable types and spelling rules.
The brains of those with dyslexia
as a functional variation in the brain,
which, naturally, shows all sorts of variations
of brain function in all humans
and suggests that to better understand the perspectives
we should try not only to see the world through their eyes
but understand it through their brains.

comments.text:
Thanks for showing me how it works I alway just thought I was dun / thick

comments.author: Peter Wladysiuk

comments.text:
I'm dyslexia witch makes my reading and righting a lot harder than needs to 
be. But I have bin told that throw my dyslexia makes that harder for me, it 
has help improve my maths witch I think it has I did my maths GCSE. Two 
years early no other kid was and some teacher was thinking I would get a F. 
But I was saying to the teacher give me harder work this is two easy and he 
said then I'll put you in for GCSE. Thinking I would say no so I did; it 
was my first time I have ever done a GCSE. I got second to best mark show 
them and for some people with dyslexia. If you struggle with the same thing 
as I do reading and righting do what I do. It makes it ten times quicker 
use a laptop or a computer. It tacks getting use two but I did my English 
GCSE on it and I got the best mark in my class. I was put up a year in 
school after my maths but after some of the things I did it looks like I 
was meant to be in that year.﻿

comments.author: Vikram Khanzode

comments.text: +MercifiesProductions same here man....
comments.author: Vikram Khanzode

comments.text:
+Vikram Khanzode You could have a mild form. I do, and my problems are 
nothing like the first paragraph. Usually I notice my dyslexia when reading 
text that is packed together. So I'll pull words from lines above and below 
what I'm reading and insert it into the sentence. I don't have trouble 
reading words regularly, but yes I have problems with words that are very 
similar.

For example: break and brake, sceptic and septic, tortuous and torturous, 
militate and mitigate, etc.


I don't replace letters of words with opposite letters, I'll just read a 
similar looking word instead of the correct one

comments.text:
Hard ones for me are: difinetely and hilerious... Yeah thats how I spelled 
them. I'm greatful for spell check. 

Don't even get me started on conjunctions, nouns, and other linguistic 
phrases. I seem to learn it and forget it just as fast. 

Side note, even while I read your words I was like this guy is just messing 
around, and then I started to type out this and I remembered how difficult 
it is. Not knowing how to spell words hurts my writing for sure.

comments.text:
Great video! HI guys, Math Utility here. We know math can be very 
challenging at times, especially for you High School students. Tons of 
homework, lots of tests to prepare for, we totally get it. That is where we 
step in. Math Utility is a 4 day old account, primarily focused on 
delivering our viewers with a easy to understand, less than 2 minute video 
about topics in Geometry and Algebra I that could be very hard to 
understand. 

If you ever need any help, or know of someone that does, PLEASE send them 
over to our page, not only for our sake, but for theirs too! They will gain 
a quick understanding of the topic in the video, and will go into that test 
or homework assignment a lot more confident in their ability. Come check us 
out, and refer us to your friends!

We take ANY recommendations on math based videos, and will do our absolute 
best to have those videos uploaded within 2 days!

Thank You and Have a Fantastic Day,
Your Math Utility Team﻿
comments.author: Math Utility

comments.author: Brainjogging

comments.text:
I'm wondering if I have dyslexia. Right now I'm working on my masters 
degree. Yes! masters degree, yet, I can't spell. I often feel embarrassed 
to go to the board and write anything. What I do, I try to write down the 
words that I have trouble with, many times, so I can remembered them. But, 
in a matter of a days or so.. I totally forget how to spell them again. I 
have struggle throughout my life, but I just notice how dumb I am, compared 
to others. If I was to compete in a spelling bee with 2nd graders, I will 
loose in the first round. And the bad thing is... that I will be a school 
teacher. Yes! an elementary school teacher. I really hope I can find a way 
to deal with this, as I really want to help kids and not hold them behind. 
However, I'm really creative, so I always find something that will deviate 
people from noticing how dumb I am, with my spelling. Another thing that I 
do in order to "sound smart" in front of  people, is that I write down 
fancy words.Yet, just like my formula to remember my spelling, I forget 
what those words mean, in a matter of days. Is this normal? Honestly, the 
only reason that I'm in school is because I dream a lot.But it's hard to 
keep up with people that really deserve to be in school.﻿
comments.author: Raul Aguilar

comments.text:
+Raul Aguilar
oh god I definitely relate! english is my second language as well, when 
people saw me having difficulties with reading Arabic, they thought I 
simply indulged myself too much in English that it affected my Arabic, but 
I have that problem with both Arabic AND English! and i have to say, not a 
lot of people where i live are educated about Dyslexia, and it's driving me 
insane!
comments.author: Reemoo4kill

comments.text:
One more thing. At first I though that it was because English is my second 
language. However, this happens with my Spanish to.

it's worth it, if you are at the right college.﻿
comments.author: The YouTube Commenter

comments.text:
I started doing that at a very early age due to my speech therapy. I can 
recognize prefixes, suffixes, and root words a lot easier because of 
syllable breakdown. That's probably why I love anatomy and physiology as my 
primary science course. Once you learn terminology once, it repeats for all 
other systems. I think the trick is pattern detection. I am a slow reader, 
but I still enjoy reading.﻿
comments.author: The YouTube Commenter

comments.text:
My name is Fred and I am dyslexic and study Neurolinguistics and other 
areas Linguistics at the University of Kent. I have taught in highschool 
with pupils with dyslexia as well as learnt with extra support systems. 
Linguistic awareness is probably the most underrated but one of the most 
important knowledge systems, once you realise what it is. I empathise with 
the hardship and remind you of your potential.﻿

hey im also dyslexia back in the 80's  i got a midea attention in my

comments.author: Shazry Azman

comments.text:
I'm counted among the severely dyslexic band, with problems like short term 
memory loss, reading issues, learning difficulties and focusing on tasks 
that seem elementary to my peers, only to name a few. subsequently spending 
most of my school years in the 'special class'. And for most of my 
childhood and teens I found it confusing why I couldn't seem to apply my 
intelligence in the same manner as my peers. when i was diagnosed with it 
at the age of 16, I felt no relief, no happiness at the answer. id wrote 
myself of years ago at ever achieving much more than a GCSE (i got 5 at C 
grade), now in the to university for my chosen field).
   I understood the problem then and i worked on it. i worked hard on 
getting better at reading, writing and the rest of my 'problems'. im not 
'better' or 'cured' of this, i wouldn't want to be; i think unique to most 
others, see things in a whole other perspective to most. look at it as a 
boon to your life; a positive thing with individual characteristics that 
can set you apart or even ahead of others. 
   its taken me years to get to the place i am now. it does take time. you 
will literally be adjusting your brain pathways. but you can improve.

(i dont write this too get sympathy, praise or whatever. simply to 
illustrate that its possible for a person who isnt famous or wealthy to get 
somewhere. want to improve and you will. if you want to any advice or need 
to talk about it please send me a message, il help the best i can)﻿
comments.author: Stefan Hetherington

comments.text:
i have dyslexia too i didn't quite cure myself but i did everything with my 
logic and my neurophysiologist was really surprised on our firs session 
now i can read normally on my native language and on English (but my 
spelling is still bad) and i have really hard time reading on 
Russian.......   ﻿
comments.author: Elene Kalandarishvili

comments.text:

comments.author: Riley Barnes

comments.text:
I am very fucking dyslexic. I am 23 and cant spell nothing. I hate it. I am 
also a slow learner. And sometimes have trouble getting my words out. I 
fill like my mind is trapped. I spent most of my life being the special one 
in class. And did not leave school with that many friends. So i ran away to 
Australia. And now been here for 3 years. No one understands how shit it 
is. I am interested in so may things. like quantum macanics. And space. But 
struggle to remember anything. I really wont to be sucssefull. And have my 
own caff one day. But dont even no if that will ever happen now. I would 
rather chop of my fucking arm than be stuck in side this metle cage. There 
is so much going on in my head but cant aritculate anything, READING THIS I 
ONLY USED SPELL CHECK ABOUT 50% OF THE TIME AND STILL CANT SPELL this is to 
give you an idear. ﻿
comments.author: Ben Robinson

comments.text: +Sandra Saenz You are fucking awsome. Thanks........
comments.author: Ben Robinson

comments.text:
+Ben Robinson A few years ago I got tired of the life I was living. I 
basically was partying, doing all kinds of drugs and hooking up with guys 
that didn't care about me. I didn't care if I lived or died at that point. 
It was January of 2011 and I almost over dosed on some ecstasy pills. I 
remember looking at myself in a mirror and asking God for help. I went to 
church that following Sunday and it felt so good to just be there. I 
listened to the surmen and it hit home so starting changing my life from 
that point on. I don't go to church anymore I think I just wanted to feel 
connected to god and now I know that our creater is within all of us at all 
times. I feel like everyone has to go through some shit so that you can 
realize who you truly are and that Is anything you want to be. You're only 
limited by your beliefs but it's taken me years to get where I am today. 
Reprogramming my mind with just positive thinking. Every day I repeat 
afermations that change all the years of shame, embarrassment and 
self-doubt. And Google has helped a lot too... lol the best advice I can 
give you is to find the things that make you feel a live and do them as 
much as you possibly can.
comments.author: Sandra Saenz

comments.text:
+Sandra Saenz Thanks for the insite maybe i should stop being a little 
bitch about it and just get on with it. Nothing is going to change it. Its 
just learning to cope with it. As you said eventurley you dont care about 
it so why should i now. Its just time wasting. I am finding now that there 
are some things i am good good at. But everything that i am good at like 
managemt and a good team leader i allways get hold back by simple paper 
work things that i just cant proses. I really have tried and its never 
going to happen. I need to figer a way to over come these probloms. What 
did you do? thanks for your incoraging reply. Cheers.
comments.author: Ben Robinson

comments.text:
Hi Ben yes I am I'm very blessed, I choose a career in social services 
witch I absolutely love. I get to help individuals every day and I go home 
knowing I made a difference in my community. But know one knows I'm dyslex 
and I'm at the point in my life where I don't care anymore so I plan on 
doing something about it. I want to help other people who are going through 
what I go through every day and teach them to build a better life for 
themselves. If you have any other questions please ask I'm here for you and 
anyone else. Much love to you!
comments.author: Sandra Saenz

comments.text:

to learn to live with it. Can i ask you a question to you make a disent 
living.

I sometimes think I have mild dyslexia I can read very well but when 
someone gives me directions like left and right I have no clue how to get 
there as a child my mother had to label my boots left and right or I would 
struggle to get the right one on I also have little to no sense of time 
passing I can't tell the difference between 5 minutes and 10 I never 
developed these skills though my teachers tried and tried everything to 
make me 'normal' but I wasn't after a change in schools I was tested with a 
simple iq test and I amazed them my Iq was 150 and I was doing grade 12 
science in grade 7 so who cares I can't tell my directions or time maybe I 
was never was suppose to fit into the mold of norm ﻿

task on paper with what i'm suppose to do with my body. i also have 
dyscalculia which means i have trouble with math i get screwed up when 
trying to count past 30 and i still have to use my fingers to do basic math 
problems like 6+9....which is 15 and yes i did just count on my fingers to 
do that.﻿

comments.author: Alex JB

comments.text:
*What is Dyslexia?*

Dyslexia Can Affect; Words, Reading, Health, Life, Career, Maths, Spelling, 
and Education

Dyslexia is something I am very passionate about.
As I recently figure that I have what looks to be Dyslexia (self 
diagnosed.) I'm in the process of getting it tested.
This had a big affect on my writing, reading, spelling, education, mental 
health and career. A lot of what dyslexia can affect played a big part in 
my perceived failures in life and lead me down some dark paths in the 
past.....

So please give Dyslexia Action New Zealand a 'like' as the team behind 
Dyslexia Action New Zealand are from my old school Kapiti College.
They have 3 goals to change New Zealand Education System to cater for 
dyslexia students in the classroom.
I'm going to get involve with Dyslexia Action New Zealand in every way 
possible to get the message out there.

So please help me out by spreading the message and getting all of your 
friend, family, co-workers to 'like' Dyslexia Action New Zealand Facebook 
page
https://www.facebook.com/DyslexiaActionNewZealand

#DyslexiaActionNewZealand 
#EducationNZ 
#government 
#NewZealand 
#Education 
#Dyslexia  ﻿

comments.text:
I would recommend Dragon NaturallySpeaking (voice recognition software) to 
anybody who is severely dyslexic like myself. You can literally speak into 
your computer and it will write down your words, don't get me wrong it's 
far from perfect but it really is life changing or it has been for me at 
least. Especially if you use it alongside text to speech software such as 
Natural Reader. It will take some perseverance, but I'm sure anybody can 
get used to it.﻿
comments.author: Joe Cornell

comments.text: I'm dyslexic and my school gives me special classes to help me out﻿
